Ayat ini seolah-olah mencela sikap dan tindakan orang-orang kafir yang menyembah patung-patung yang mereka buat sendiri yang tidak dapat memberi manfaat dan mudarat bahkan harus mereka sendiri yang memelihara dan merawatnya. Demikian pula sikap orang-orang kafir yang selalu membangga-banggakan kekayaan, kekuasaan, dan keturunan mereka, sebagaimana Allah berfirman:

Dan mereka berkata, "Kami memiliki lebih banyak harta dan anak-anak (daripada kamu) dan kami tidak akan diazab." (Saba'/34: 35)

Karena kekafiran itu, mereka tidak akan memperoleh kesenangan hidup di akhirat nanti. Kelak mereka akan mengetahui, siapa di antara mereka dan orang-orang mukmin yang menempuh jalan yang benar dan siapa yang menempuh jalan yang sesat. Yang menempuh jalan yang benar sampai ke tempat yang baik penuh kenikmatan dan yang menempuh jalan yang sesat tentu akan sampai di tempat yang sesat pula, penuh kesengsaraan dan penderitaan.
text.30:
Dalam ayat ini, Allah menerangkan lagi tanda-tanda kebesaran dan kekuasaan-Nya, setelah pada ayat yang lalu Dia memerintahkan agar bertawakal kepada-Nya. Allah memerintahkan Muhammad mengatakan kepada orang-orang kafir, "Hai orang-orang kafir, cobalah terangkan kepadaku, apa yang terpikir olehmu, seandainya atas kehendak Allah seluruh air yang mengalir di permukaan bumi ini meresap ke dalam tanah, sehingga sumber-sumber air dan sumurmu menjadi kering, timba-timbamu tidak dapat menimba air lagi. Apakah tuhanmu yang lain dapat mendatangkan air itu, sehingga kamu dapat minum, kebun-kebunmu menjadi subur kembali dan binatang-binatang ternakmu dapat berkembang biak? Tidak ada sesuatu pun yang dapat mendatangkan air itu kecuali Allah Yang Maha Pemurah dan Penyayang kepada hamba-hamba-Nya. Kenapa kamu masih menyekutukan-Nya dengan sesuatu yang tidak layak bagi-Nya?"

Ayat ini menyuruh orang-orang kafir membandingkan dasar ketuhanan menurut pengertian mereka dengan sifat pemahaman ketuhanan menurut agama yang disampaikan Muhammad saw. Tuhan yang disembah menurut yang diajarkan Rasulullah adalah Tuhan pencipta seluruh makhluk, dan menjaga kelangsungan hidup semua yang hidup di alam ini. Dia Mahakuasa dan Maha Menentukan segala sesuatu, tidak memerlukan sesuatu apa pun untuk menolong-Nya dan sebagainya. Bukan Tuhan yang dibuat manusia atau diangkat oleh manusia sendiri untuk disembah, seperti pemahaman ketuhanan orang-orang musyrik. Ayat ini seakan mengingatkan mereka bahwa Tuhan yang pantas disembah itu hanyalah Tuhan Yang Maha Esa, tidak beranak, tidak dilahirkan, tidak berserikat dengan suatu apa pun, dan tidak memerlukan makhluk-makhluk lain untuk membantu-Nya melaksanakan setiap urusan.

en.name: The Sovereignty
en.source: Aplikasi Quran Kementrian Agama Republik Indonesia

text.1:
This verse explains that Allah, the Most Holy and Whose mercy is limitless, is the ruler of all the kingdoms of this mortal world with all its contents, and the kingdom of the hereafter which occurs after the disappearance of the kingdom of the world. Allah says:

And to Allah belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and whatever is between them. He creates what He wills, and Allah is over all things competent. (al-Ma'idah/5: 17)

Another saying of Allah:

[All] praise is [due] to Allah, Lord of the worlds - The Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful, Sovereign of the Day of Recompense. (al-Fatihah/1: 2-4)

Allah is the ruler of the kingdom of the world. This means that He is the One who created this entire universe with everything in it. He is also the One who develops, maintains its existence, regulates, manages, controls, and determines everything in it, according to His will. In regulating, managing, developing, and maintaining the existence of this universe, Allah establishes laws and regulations. All are obligated to submit to and follow the laws and regulations He has made without any exception whatsoever. Anyone or anything that does not want to submit and obey, and denies these laws and regulations will surely perish or suffer.

Allah's laws and regulations that apply in this universe are two; first, *sunatullah*, which are Allah's laws and provisions that apply in this universe, both for living things and inanimate objects, both for humans and for animals, plants, and inanimate objects, both for the earth with all its contents and for all the planets that orbit in the vast universe. Among Allah's laws and regulations are that fire burns, water flows from a high place to a low place, Pascal's law, and Archimedes' law. Humans need oxygen, food and drink to live, both in the form of physical and spiritual food and drink. Humans are individual and social beings. Each planet, including the earth, has its own gravitational pull and moves on its predetermined orbit; and there are many more of Allah's laws and regulations, both those that humans have known and those that they have not yet known.

Violation of Allah's laws and regulations means suffering and destruction for the violator. Like putting a hand into fire resulting in the burning of the hand, and damaging nature or cutting down forests excessively resulting in floods and losses for humans. Even stars and meteors that violate Allah's laws will experience destruction.

Second, the religion of Allah, which contains guidance for humans. By following these guidelines, humans will live happily in this world and in the hereafter. The religion containing these guidelines was revealed by Allah to the messengers He sent, from Prophet Adam to Prophet Muhammad, as the last prophet and messenger of Allah, the seal of all messengers and prophets. Humans who live after the sending of Prophet Muhammad, until the end of time, are obligated to follow the religion he brought if they want to live safely and happily in this world and in the hereafter.

Thus, Allah, who controls, manages, regulates, and maintains the existence of this universe, establishes laws and provisions, so that everything appears orderly, beautiful, and beneficial to humans. If a citizen is obligated to submit to and obey all the laws and provisions that apply in his country, then he must be even more obligated to submit to and obey the laws and regulations of Allah who created, gives blessings, and protects him. If a country imposes sanctions on every citizen who violates the laws and regulations it has established, then Allah is more likely to impose sanctions and judge fairly every creature who denies the laws and regulations He has made.

In addition to being the ruler of the kingdom of the world, Allah also rules the kingdom of the hereafter, which exists after the destruction of the entire kingdom of the world. The kingdom of the hereafter is an eternal kingdom; starting from the occurrence of the Day of Judgment, the day of the destruction of the world and the resurrection of humans from the grave. Then they are gathered in Padang Mahsyar to be judged and weighed for their deeds and actions. From that trial it is decided; for those whose faith and good deeds outweigh the mistakes they have made, then they are rewarded with paradise, a place full of pleasure and happiness. Conversely, if the evil deeds they have done during their life in the world outweigh the faith and good deeds they have done, then the reward they receive is hell, a place full of unparalleled misery. Life in the hereafter, both in paradise and in hell, is eternal life. In paradise, Allah bestows blessings and happiness upon those who believe and do good deeds, while in hell, Allah inflicts severe punishment upon those who disbelieve and do evil.

Allah says:

Yes, whoever earns evil and his sin has encompassed him - those are the companions of the Fire; they will abide therein eternally. But those who believe and do righteous deeds - those are the companions of Paradise; they will abide therein eternally. (al-Baqarah/2: 81-82)

At the end of this verse, it is emphasized that Allah, as the ruler of the kingdom of the world and the kingdom of the hereafter, is All-Powerful over all things. There is nothing that can match His power and nothing that can escape His power.
text.2:
In this verse, it is explained that God, who holds the power of the kingdom of the world and the kingdom of the hereafter and controls everything, is the God who creates death and life. Only He determines the time of death for every creature. If that time of death has arrived, nothing can hasten or delay it even for a moment. Likewise, the condition of the creature that will die, nothing can change it from what He has determined. Allah says:

And Allah will never delay the death of anyone when their time comes. And Allah is All-Aware of what you do. (al-Munafiqun/63: 11)

No human or other living creature can escape the death that Allah has decreed, as His saying:

Wherever you may be, death will overtake you, even if you should be within fortified towers. (an-Nisa'/4: 78)

Similarly, it is stated that Allah creates life. This means that He is the one who gives life to all living creatures in this universe. He provides all their needs for life, and He also provides the possibility of the continuation of the species of living creatures, so that they are not threatened with extinction. Then He also determines the length of life of a creature and determines the state of life of all creatures. At the same time, Allah also determines until when the survival of a creature will last, so that when the time He has determined has ended, the species of that creature becomes extinct, as experienced by ancient animal species.

In this verse, it is explained that Allah created death and life to test humans, who among them believe and do good deeds by following the guidance brought by Prophet Muhammad, and who deny it. From the verse above, it is understood that by creating life, Allah gives humans a very wide opportunity to choose what is good for themselves. Whether they will follow their desires, or they will follow the guidance, laws, and provisions of Allah as the ruler of the universe. If humans are afflicted with a painful torment in the hereafter, then that torment is essentially inflicted upon their own will. Likewise, if they obtain happiness, then that happiness comes because of their own will while living in the world.

Based on that test, the degree and status of a human being in the sight of Allah is also determined. The stronger a person's faith, the more good deeds they do. The more they submit and obey Allah's laws and regulations, the higher the degree and status they obtain in the sight of Allah. Conversely, if a person does not believe in Him, does not do good deeds, and is not obedient to Him, they will obtain the most despicable place in the hereafter.

Worldly life is to test humans, who among them always use their minds and thoughts to understand the religion of Allah, and choose which actions are best to do, so that their actions are pleasing to Allah. Also to know who is patient and able to restrain themselves from doing what Allah has forbidden, and who is most obedient to Him.

This verse encourages and advises humans to always be vigilant in their lives. They should always examine their hearts whether they are truly believers, and also examine everything they will do, whether it is in accordance with what Allah has commanded or not, and whether what they will do is forbidden by Allah or not. If the action is in accordance with Allah's command, even including actions that are pleasing to Him, then they should immediately do it. Conversely, if the action is included in Allah's prohibitions, then never carry it out.

At the end of this verse, Allah affirms that He is All-Powerful, no creature can hinder His will if He intends to do something, such as giving rewards to those who believe and do good deeds or intending to punish those who are disobedient to Him. He is All-Forgiving to His servants who repent to Him by regretting the sinful deeds they have done, promising not to commit that sin again, and also promising not to commit other sins.

In this verse, Allah mentions two kinds of His attributes together, namely the attribute of All-Powerful and All-Forgiving, as if these two attributes are contradictory. The attribute of All-Powerful gives the understanding of giving frightening news, while the attribute of All-Forgiving gives the understanding of hope for everyone who commits sinful deeds, if they repent. This shows that Allah, who has the right to be worshiped, can truly impose His will on anyone, and no one can hinder Him. He knows everything, so He can give the right reward to each of His servants, whether in the form of reward or punishment. With that knowledge, He can also distinguish between those who are obedient and disobedient to Him, so there is no possibility whatsoever for a disobedient person to obtain a reward or an obedient and submissive person to obtain punishment. Allah never makes mistakes in giving retribution.

Another word of Allah that mentions warning and hope together is:

Inform My servants that it is I who am the Forgiving, the Merciful, and that My punishment is indeed the most painful punishment. (al-Hijr/15: 49-50)
text.3:
Allah explains that He is the One who created all the heavens in layers in the universe. Each celestial body seems to float firmly in the middle of the cosmos, without any supporting pillars and without any binding ropes. Each heaven occupies a space that has been determined for it in the middle of the cosmos, and each layer consists of so many planets that are countless. Each planet moves along its predetermined orbit. Allah says:

He created the heavens without pillars that you can see, and He placed mountains on the earth so it would not shake you, and He dispersed throughout it every kind of living creature. And We send down rain from the sky and cause to grow therein every noble plant. (Luqman/31: 10)

All celestial bodies along with the stars contained within them are submissive and obedient to the provisions and laws that Allah has established for them. Everything remains as such until the time appointed for it. Allah says:

Allah is the One who erected the heavens without pillars that you can see, then He established Himself above the Throne ('Arsy). He subjected the sun and the moon, each running [its course] for a specified term. He arranges [each] matter, and He details the signs that you may be certain of meeting your Lord. (ar-Ra'd/13: 2)

According to Astronomy, in the vast universe, there are galaxies or clusters of stars containing billions of stars that are countless. Some of the stars within each galaxy are small like the earth, and some are large like the sun, and many are even larger. Each galaxy has a neatly organized system, which is inseparable from the entire space system. The attraction that exists on each planet causes the planets not to fall and not to collide with one another, so that they remain floating and orbiting in their respective orbits in space.

If the meaning of the verse is connected with what is explained by Astronomy, then what is meant by the many levels of the heavens are galaxies. Meanwhile, the number seven in Arabic is commonly used to indicate something that is numerous. Therefore, what is meant by the seven levels of the heavens are the many galaxies that exist in the sky. Meanwhile, there are also interpreters who argue that what is meant by "seven layers of heaven" are seven planets around the sun, and there are also interpreters who do not want to interpret it. They surrender it to Allah because it is in His knowledge which has not been known with certainty by humans.

Such is a general picture of the state of the galaxy system. Regarding the condition of each planet, which is countless, such as what its nature and characteristics are, what is contained within it, what its shape is in detail, and so on, very little is known to humans. Even that is only a small fraction of knowledge about the galaxy.

As for the creation of the seven layers of "heaven," it is found in several other verses, such as al-Baqarah/2: 29, al-An'am/6: 125, Nuh/71: 15, and an-Naba'/78: 12. According to scientists, the word heaven can be interpreted as the earth's sky in the form of the atmosphere or the sky of the universe. If it is the earth's sky, it turns out that the atmosphere is divided into seven layers. And each layer has a task and function to protect the earth.

The division of the atmosphere into seven layers is based on differences in chemical content and air temperature. The seven layers are called: Troposphere, Stratosphere, Mesosphere layers, Thermosphere, Exosphere, Ionosphere, and Magnetosphere. In Surah Fussilat/41 verses 11-12 it is stated that each layer of heaven has its own affairs. This is confirmed by science, for example, there is a layer whose job is to make rain, prevent damage from radiation, reflect radio waves, up to a layer that prevents meteors from damaging the earth.

However, with the existence of verse 5 in the same surah (al-Mulk/67: 5), it seems that what is meant by heaven is not the atmospheric sky, but the sky of the universe. The verse reads:

And We have certainly beautified the nearest heaven with stars and made them as missiles for devils and have prepared for them the punishment of the Blaze. (al-Mulk/67: 5)

It is clearly stated that the "nearest heaven" (perhaps it can be interpreted as the first layer of heaven) is decorated with stars. The word used is not star (singular form that can refer to the sun as a star in the solar system), but stars (plural form). Thus, the "nearest heaven" is the entire galaxy that we know today.

If this is the case, what is stated in the Qur'an regarding this matter has not been reached by scientific findings at all. In connection with that, it is very arrogant if a human being claims to know everything. No matter how vast a person's knowledge is, it is still very little compared to the knowledge of Allah. If a person likens himself to the earth, then sees himself lying among the many planets, he will certainly feel that he is actually meaningless when compared to Allah's creatures of various shapes and patterns that are countless.

Allah then commands humans to look at and pay attention to the heavens and the earth and their contents, and to study their properties. For example, observe the sun shining and the moon shining, to what extent the benefits and advantages of the rays and light are for the life of all creatures that exist. Observe the livestock grazing in the meadows, the green plants, the high and sturdy mountains that soothe the eyes of those who look at them; the vast blue sea; the sky and all its contents. Everything grows, develops, remains in the continuity of life and its form, and is continuous and has a very neat system, laws, and regulations. The system is inseparable from a system of laws and regulations that is greater than it, which applies to the entire mortal world. Try to think and reflect, is there any defect or flaw in the creatures created by Allah, as well as in the system, laws and regulations that apply to them? Great and Creator is Allah, Lord of all the worlds, there is no defect or flaw in the creatures He created.

Then, as if Allah continues His question to humans, are they still doubtful about His power and greatness? Are humans still doubtful about the system, laws, and regulations made for His creatures, including themselves? If they are still doubtful, humans are ordered to pay attention, reflect, and study again in truth. Do they still find in Allah's creation something that is imperfect?

From the question raised in this verse, it can be understood that it is as if Allah is challenging humans to look for (if there is) even a slight deficiency and imperfection in His creation. If there are deficiencies, defects, and flaws in Allah's creation, then humans deserve to deny His oneness and power. However, they are amazed and acknowledge the neatness of Allah's creation, and they even acknowledge their weaknesses. If this is the case, then their denial is not caused by their disbelief in Allah, but solely because of their arrogance and pride.
text.4:
Allah's question to mankind in the verse above is answered by Allah Himself in this verse by saying that even if humans repeatedly observe, study, and contemplate all of Allah's creations, they will certainly not find any shortcomings or defects, not even the slightest. If they continuously do so, even if their entire life and existence is used for it, in the end, they will only feel and will not find any shortcomings, until they die and return to their Lord.

From this verse, it can be understood that no one among mankind is able to find flaws in Allah's creation. If there is anyone among mankind who is capable of doing so, it means that he knows all of Allah's knowledge. Until now, no one has known it and no one will be able to possess all of Allah's knowledge. Even if there is someone among mankind who is considered to have the broadest knowledge, then the knowledge he knows is only a small part of Allah's knowledge. However, many among mankind do not want to realize their weaknesses and shortcomings, so they remain in denial of Him.
text.5:
After stating that there is not the slightest deficiency in His creation, Allah affirms that He is the Almighty and Most Great Lord, by saying that He has adorned the nearest heaven to the earth with the sun that shines brightly during the day, the moon and stars that shine at night, which can be seen by humans every day and night. The sky adorned with the sun, moon, and shining stars is seen by humans as if it were a house adorned with glittering lights at night, pleasing the hearts of those who look at it.

The analogy presented in the verse above is a beautiful and direct analogy. Namely, that the universe is likened to a house. A house is a place for humans to live, a place to take shelter from the heat of the sun and a place to take shelter in the rain, a place for them to have fun and rest, a place for them to raise their children, and so on. Thus, this universe was created by Allah for the benefit of all mankind.

Besides adorning the sky, the stars can also produce flames that can be used to pelt the accursed devils who eavesdrop on the conversations of the inhabitants of the heavens.

Some scholars interpret this verse by saying that Allah created the stars as decorations for the world and to generate sustenance for humans, namely through the existence of day and night with all kinds of benefits that can be obtained from them. The sustenance obtained by humans because of the existence of day and night, some of which become the cause of goodness and some of which become the cause of evil that can ignite evil desires.

Qatadah said that Allah created the stars with three purposes, namely: first, to decorate the sky; second, to throw at devils; and third, to be a guide for directions and addresses for travelers who are on a journey, whether on land, sea, or in this vast outer space. Perhaps Qatadah explained among the purposes of Allah creating the stars as far as he knew, because there are still many other purposes, both known and unknown to humans. Allah is Vast in His knowledge and Most Wise.

Thus, Allah created the stars that adorn the universe in countless numbers. All of this can be utilized by humans according to the desires they want to achieve. If the desire to be achieved is a desire that is in accordance with the pleasure of Allah, then Allah will certainly ease the way for the achievement of that desire and give him manifold rewards. Conversely, if the desire to be achieved is a desire that is contrary to the pleasure of Allah, then a painful torment is prepared for them.
text.6:
It has been decreed and is the *sunnatullah* that everyone who associates partners with Allah, denies Him, and rejects the messengers He sent, will be cast into Hell. That is the worst place prepared for them. In it, they will experience extremely painful and agonizing suffering.

Then Allah explains the attitude of Hell at the time the disbelievers are thrown into it, namely:

1. When the disbelievers are thrown into it, its roaring and terrifying sound is heard as a sign of its anger.

2. Hell boils, like a large pot boiling the disbelievers with its boiling water.

3. Hell is as if it is about to burst when the disbelievers are thrown into it.

4. Hell is very fierce and angry at everyone who is in it.

5. Every time a group of disbelievers is thrown into it, the keepers of Hell rebuke them, "Did a messenger not come to you? Why did you not follow the call of the messengers conveyed to you?"

6. The inhabitants of Hell acknowledge that messengers had come to them, but they denied them; even accusing the messengers of being in error.
text.7: In this verse, the state of Hell is explained as a place prepared for the disbelievers, as well as their attitude when they are thrown into it. At the time when the disbelievers are thrown into it, they will hear a roaring sound that is extremely loud and terrifying. Hell will be heard seething as if it were a large pot, and the disbelievers will be boiled in it with boiling and seething water because of its heat.
text.8:
Furthermore, it is explained that Hell receives the disbelievers with intense fury. So great is its anger that it almost bursts into pieces. In this state, the angels of Zabaniyah rebuke and reproach them, "Did there not come to you a messenger sent by Allah who warned you of the torment of the Day of Resurrection that befalls you at this moment?" This also shows that Allah will not punish a people unless He sends a messenger and they disregard the call. In another verse, Allah says:

"But We never punish until We have sent a messenger." (al-Isra'/17: 15)

From this verse, it can be understood that humans are required to carry out the commands of Allah and abandon His prohibitions if the call of the messenger sent to them has been conveyed to them. This applies whether the call is conveyed directly or indirectly, that is, through people who have believed in Him.
text.9:
In this verse, it is explained that the question of the angels is answered by the disbelievers who are being punished by acknowledging that a messenger had come to them. He had recited to them the verses of God and had warned them of the consequences that would befall those who did not heed the call. However, they denied and even mocked the messengers by saying; "O you who have claimed to receive revelation from Allah. In reality, no revelation has been sent down to you by Allah because you are not a messenger sent to us. You are only ordinary human beings like us, even poorer and lower in status than us. There is no use or benefit whatsoever in all the words you utter to us, indeed, all of you who claim to be messengers sent by God are actually people who are in great error." In another verse, Allah says:

"And those who disbelieved will be driven to Hell in groups until, when they reach it, its gates are opened and its keepers will say, "Did there not come to you messengers from yourselves, reciting to you the verses of your Lord and warning you of the meeting of this Day of yours?" They will say, "Yes, [there did]," but the decree of punishment has come into effect upon the disbelievers." (az-Zumar/39: 71)
text.10: In this verse, Allah explains that the disbelievers who are being punished in hell regret their attitudes and actions during their lives in the world, saying, "If only we had used our reason and intellect that Allah had bestowed upon us, to evaluate and benefit from the call of the Messenger, and if only we had used our ears to hear the verses of Allah that were revealed and conveyed to us by the Messenger He sent, then surely we would not have denied and rejected the truth that was conveyed. We would not have been deceived by the pleasures and influence of this fleeting world, nor would we have been deceived by the deception of Satan, and we would not have been cast into this blazing hell whose torment is unbearable for us in the slightest."
text.11:
In this verse, Allah also explains that even if the disbelievers who are being punished in hell acknowledge the sins they committed during their lives in the world and sincerely repent, their acknowledgment and repentance will be of no benefit whatsoever. This is because the repentance accepted by Allah is only the repentance performed by a person while they are alive in the world, with the following conditions:

1. Immediately abandoning the sin committed.

2. Regretting the sin committed.

3. Promising not to commit the sin that has been committed and other actions prohibited by Allah.

In the hereafter, the disbelievers have been distanced from Allah's mercy, so that anything in the form of His mercy, such as forgiveness of sins, happiness in life, and so on, will no longer be obtainable for them. Only destruction will befall them.

From this verse, it can be understood that the call to embrace the religion of Allah and follow the call of the Messenger has actually reached almost every place in the world and to all people. Meanwhile, the teachings of the religion conveyed by the Messenger are easily accepted and implemented by any human being who has reached puberty and is of sound mind, because the purpose of the religious teachings is for the benefit of mankind in life in this world and in the hereafter, not to burden and constrict. In addition, religious teachings are easily accepted by a sound mind because they are easy to understand and in accordance with human reason. However, because of lust, position, rank, wealth, and the desire to gain sympathy, honor, and coupled with the temptations of Satan whose only goal is to mislead mankind, they do not heed the call. As a result, they receive a reward commensurate with their disbelief and denial. How many people who were initially believers and practiced the teachings of Islam well, but then because of the influence of lust and the temptations of Satan, they do not hesitate to abandon the beliefs and convictions that have grown luxuriantly in their hearts, and they even do not hesitate to destroy Islam and the Muslims.

Allah Himself always reminds them by giving trials in the form of pleasure and suffering, but they are only aware until the trial disappears from them. After that, they return to denying the teachings and the call of the Messenger. Therefore, it is fitting that in the hereafter they will not receive help from Allah and will be distanced from His mercy.
text.12:
This verse explains the signs of the God-fearing who are submissive and obedient to Allah, and are certain that Allah knows everything they do, both apparent and hidden.

These signs are:

1.  Constantly fearing the punishment of Allah, even though that punishment is unseen, invisible, and its arrival is uncertain.

2.  Feeling fear of the arrival of the Day of Judgment, remembering the calamities that will befall them if they deny Allah, such as the events that will occur on the Day of Reckoning, the Day of Retribution, and the unimaginable torment of Hell.

3.  Being certain and believing that Allah is always watching, observing, and knowing where and in what condition they are at all times.

In a hadith of Prophet Muhammad it is mentioned:

From Abu Hurairah, he said, the Messenger of Allah (saw) said, "A person who weeps out of fear of Allah will not enter Hell." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi, an-Nasa'i, Ahmad, al-Hakim, and others)

Those who truly believe in Allah and do righteous deeds, there is no fear for them, nor will they grieve over anything they have missed, as Allah says:

Indeed, those who believe and do righteous deeds and establish prayer and give zakah will have their reward with their Lord, and there will be no fear concerning them, nor will they grieve. (al-Baqarah/2: 277)

Those who believe and are obedient to Allah always feel that they are under His supervision. They are certain that He sees and observes them, as the Prophet Muhammad said in the context of ihsan:

"That you worship Allah as if you see Him, and if you do not see Him, then indeed He sees you." (Narrated by al-Bukhari, Muslim, and Abu Hurairah)

Allah promises that those believers who possess these qualities will have their sins forgiven and will be given a great reward in the Hereafter.
text.13:
According to a narration from Ibn 'Abbas, he said, "Once, the polytheists gossiped about the Prophet Muhammad and spoke ill of him, so Allah revealed to him everything they were saying. Then some of them said to others, "Lower your voices so that your words are not heard by the God of Muhammad." Then this verse was revealed, which, among other things, explains that nothing escapes the knowledge of Allah.

In this verse, Allah again explains that He knows everything that is concealed and everything that is manifested by His servants, whether in the form of words, deeds, and everything that is felt by the heart and the senses. None of it escapes the knowledge of Allah, because He is the All-Knowing of what is in the hearts.

From this verse, it can also be concluded that all prayers offered to Allah, whether in a loud voice, whispered, gently, or even with a movement of the heart alone, will be known to Allah.
text.14:
This verse seems to warn the polytheists who do not believe in the vastness and detail of Allah's knowledge, that God knows all the contents of the heavens and the earth, no matter how small, no matter how far hidden, and knows the words that are kept secret. Indeed, Allah's knowledge can penetrate very thick and sturdy walls and even the most hidden places.

If the disbelievers would use their minds, they would certainly conclude that the One who created the entire universe, including the earth with all its contents, is Allah. The Creator must know the condition and characteristics of His creation, both small and large. Therefore, whatever happens to His creation, Allah knows it in detail.
text.15:
This verse explains Allah's infinite blessings bestowed upon humanity, stating that Allah created the earth and made it easy for them, so they can take countless benefits for their lives. He created the earth round and floating in vast space. Humans live on it as if on a flat, calm, and unshakeable place. With the earth's rotation, night and day occur, so humans can work during the day and rest at night. The earth emits springs, which flow water for humans and their livestock to drink.

With that water, humans also irrigate their gardens and rice fields, as well as ponds where they raise fish. With that water, they bathe to cleanse their dirty bodies, so they feel refreshed and comfortable. He also created hills, valleys, and green mountains that soothe the hearts of those who look at them. From the crevices of the hills flow rivers, and between the hills and valleys, humans make roads that connect one country to another. How many blessings Allah has bestowed upon humanity. If Allah withheld just one blessing from humans, for example, not providing air to breathe, humans would suffer greatly. Who can deny Allah's countless blessings?

According to scientists, the earth, enveloped by the atmosphere, is very dynamic. Geological processes, including erosion, sedimentation, sea-level changes, earthquakes, magma movement, and volcanic eruptions over millions of years, have enabled the formation of mineral and energy deposits. In other parts, the ocean and atmosphere are equally dynamic. Their interaction with the land and their journey with the moon around the sun form climate and seasons. These dynamic processes involving land, sea, and atmosphere enable the hydrological cycle, which in turn brings rain and causes soil fertility and the formation of water reserves in lakes, rivers, and underground. Oxygen and water, which are vital human needs, are abundantly available and very easy to obtain.

This verse states that with His *rahman* (Most Gracious) nature towards all mankind, Allah has not only provided all the facilities and infrastructure for humans. He has also made it easy for humans to live on the surface of the earth. Humans are commanded by Allah to walk on the surface of the earth to recognize its places, its inhabitants, its people, its animals, and its plants.

Humans are not only given air, plants, animals, and pleasant weather, but also given equipment and comfort to seek sustenance on earth with everything on it and contained within it.

After Allah explains that this universe was created for humans and made easy for their needs, He commands them to walk on the face of the earth, to observe the beauty of nature, to strive to cultivate this easy nature, to trade, raise livestock, farm, and seek lawful sustenance. Because everything that Allah provides must be processed and worked on first before being used for human life.

By understanding this verse, the following points can be made:

1. Allah commands humans to strive and cultivate nature for their benefit in order to obtain lawful sustenance. This means that being unwilling to strive and being lazy is contrary to Allah's command.

2. Because striving and seeking sustenance is part of carrying out Allah's command, then those who strive and seek sustenance are those who obey Allah, and that is considered worship. In other words, striving and seeking sustenance does not reduce worship, but strengthens and increases worship itself.

Narrated by Ahmad from 'Umar bin al-Khaththab, he heard the Messenger of Allah say:

If you truly put your trust (*tawakkal*) in Allah, He would provide for you as He provides for the birds. They go out in the morning with empty stomachs and return in the evening with full stomachs. (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi, Ahmad, al-Baihaqi, and Abu Dawud from 'Umar bin al-Khaththab)

This *hadith* shows that the time from morning to evening is the time to seek sustenance, as the birds have done. If humans are truly willing to strive from morning to evening, Allah will surely give them sustenance. They will not go hungry. From this *hadith* it can also be understood that those who are unwilling to strive will not be given sustenance by Allah.

Narrated by al-Hakim and at-Tirmidhi from Mu'awiyah bin Qurrah, he said, "One day 'Umar bin Khaththab passed through the village of a people, then he asked the people, "Who are you?" They replied, "We are people who put our trust (*tawakkal*) in Allah." Umar said, "You are not people who put your trust in Allah, but rather people who have been eaten by rust. As for those who put their trust in Allah, they are those who plant seeds in the ground, then they put their trust in Allah."

In seeking sustenance, Islamic teachings provide several guidelines:

1. That every human being should strive to meet the needs of himself and his family. Therefore, a person who leaves his house in the morning to seek sustenance is among those who are prayed for by the Prophet Muhammad to be blessed by Allah.

That the Prophet Muhammad saw said, "O Allah, bless my *ummah* who go out striving early in the morning." (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi from Sakhr bin al-Gamidi)

2. In striving, one should seek what is *halal* (permissible). The intention is to seek sustenance in *halal* ways, not by stealing, cheating, corruption, and so on. The sustenance sought is *halal* sustenance, not *haram* (forbidden), such as *khamr* (intoxicants), carrion, and so on, according to the *hadith*: From Ali that the Messenger of Allah saw said, "Indeed, Allah Ta'ala is pleased to see His servant seeking what is *halal*." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani)

Another *hadith* explains:

From Anas bin Malik that the Messenger of Allah saw said, "Seeking *halal* sustenance is obligatory for every Muslim." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani)

At the end of the verse, Allah warns humans that all creatures will return to Him on the Day of Judgment, and at that time all human deeds will be weighed. Good deeds will be rewarded with multiplied rewards, while bad deeds will be rewarded with the torment of hell. Therefore, humans should always be self-aware, strive to carry out as many righteous deeds as possible, and assess and examine the deeds that will be done, striving to ask forgiveness from Allah for mistakes that have been made or unknowingly that the deed is included in deeds that are forbidden by Allah. Then every Muslim should seek only *halal* sustenance, never eating sustenance obtained in a *haram* way or the object itself is a *haram* object. Remember that all creatures without exception will return to Him. Allah is All-Knowing of everything.
text.16: In this verse, Allah warns the disbelievers about the torment that will befall them if they persist in disbelief. This warning is given by Allah because they seem to feel that they will be spared from Allah's punishment, which will be inflicted upon them; they even feel that they have received mercy, namely the worldly pleasures they are experiencing. The signs of disbelief are visible in their attitudes, actions, and behavior. Therefore, Allah warns them by saying, "O disbelievers, do you feel safe and will be spared from Allah's torment, even though that torment will surely befall you? Is it impossible for Allah to eliminate the power and pleasure you have obtained, even though that power and pleasure come solely from His mercy? Is it not possible that it is a test from Allah for you? Remember, Allah has inflicted terrible torment on people of the past, such as the torment inflicted on Qarun and his followers. They were sunk into the earth. At the moment Allah was about to sink them into the earth, a terrible earthquake occurred that shook the earth."
text.17:
In this verse, Allah continues His warning, "Do you then feel secure that you will be safe from Allah's punishment, which could at any moment send a wind mixed with stones that can destroy you all instantly? Remember, a punishment like this befell the people of Lut, because they denied Prophet Lut who was sent to them. At the time of the arrival of that punishment, you will all witness how terrible Our punishment is, but your knowledge at that time will be of no use."

In another verse, Allah says:

Say, "He is the [one] Able to send upon you affliction from above you or from under your feet or to confuse you [so you become] sects and make you taste the violence of one another." Look how We diversify the signs that they might understand. (al-An'am/6: 65)

Another saying of Allah:

Then do you feel secure that He will not cause a section of land to swallow you or send against you a storm of gravel? Then you would not find for yourselves an advocate. (al-Isra'/17: 68)
text.18: Then Allah commanded the disbelievers to pay attention to the suffering experienced by previous peoples, because they had denied the messengers who had been sent to them. Among them were the people of Noah who were drowned in a devastating flood, the people of Shu'aib who were destroyed by lightning, and Pharaoh and his people who were drowned in the Red Sea. They all only regretted their actions when the torment came upon them. All of this can be a lesson to contemplate and pay attention to, how terrible is the punishment of Allah inflicted upon those who are disobedient to Him.
text.19:
Allah explains that He is the All-Powerful and the All-Determining of everything. One proof of this is His power to hold birds in the sky, so they do not fall to the earth. Birds in the sky sometimes soar by spreading their wings. They fly high or swoop down, as if they will crash to the earth. Sometimes they fold their wings. Who holds the bird from falling when it spreads and folds its wings? Isn't this contrary to the law of nature that heavy objects will fall to the earth due to the earth's attraction (gravity)?

A similar thing can also be seen in the verse below.

Do they not see the birds controlled in the atmosphere of the sky? None holds them [aloft] except Allah. Indeed in that are signs for a people who believe. (an-Nahl/16: 79)

Scientifically, it can be explained that a bird's ability to fly is unique. To be able to fly, a bird should be very light. To be able to take off and continue flying in the air, birds must be light enough. At the same time, it must also be very strong and resilient. Strength is needed to be able to stay in flight for a long time, and to maneuver to catch prey or when descending to their perches.

A bird's neck bones must be strong and flexible. The number of neck vertebrae varies, some have 11 and some have more. Neck flexibility is obtained from a group of muscles that work very efficiently. Flexibility is needed for various purposes. Such as in seabirds that snatch fish at very high speeds.

Bird bones are generally hollow in the middle and have thin walls. The weight of the bird's body is placed in the middle of the body. In the chest there is a large sternum attached to the large pectoral muscles. It is these pectoral muscles that move the wings. The pectoral muscles comprise about 25-30% of the total body weight of the bird.

The pectoral muscles that work hard to move the wings quite interfere with the work of the lungs. To overcome this, birds have a different respiratory system. The respiratory system used is the spread of air sacs throughout the body. Such sacs can also be found in the hollow middle part of the bone. Air is channeled to all parts of the bird's body and absorbed by the blood quickly. Absorption is fast because of the very strong heartbeat.

Sharp vision is a primary requirement. Birds are the animals that rely most on sight in their lives. In some birds, the size of their eyes even exceeds the size of their brains. Birds can see eight times more clearly into the distance than humans. Their eyes can adapt quickly to switch from seeing near to seeing far, and vice versa.

The most important thing for a bird to be able to fly is the presence of wings and feathers. The wing is a kind of hand that has a large and strong ball joint at the shoulder. This joint is very special, and is used for very complex mobility. Its usefulness is so that the bird can maneuver well in the air. This ball joint can position the wing so that the bird can rotate quickly, change direction, slow down, fly backwards, dive at high speed, and land gracefully.

With the movement of spreading and folding its wings, the birds are actually flapping their wings to generate aerodynamic force, which is to collect enough air pressure under their wings, which will provide lift and thrust to the birds to be able to fly. This lift is to counteract the weight of the bird, while the thrust is to counteract air resistance. These two forces are generated by the flapping motion of the bird's wings with an upward, downward, and backward cycle continuously and periodically. How Generous is Allah. If He willed to eliminate the air, surely the birds would not be able to fly.

Wing feathers are a beautiful creation of God. Light, yet strong, flexible, versatile, easy to care for, functions as a heat insulator, waterproof, and can be replaced. Feather color is very important for birds. Some birds have colors that match their environment so they function for camouflage. Others use their color to attract the opposite sex.

Many types of birds migrate and travel very long distances. In doing this, they have various ways to conserve energy on this long journey. The shape of the flying formation in groups resembling the letter V in most ducks or geese during migration, turns out to have a specific purpose. This formation turns out to save energy for the entire group. This is because the V formation produces a favorable airflow. In certain positions in this formation, individual birds can rest because they are supported by an airflow pattern that allows them to rest. Who taught them?

Now we know that birds disappear from one place because they move to another place. We know when they leave, where they are going, and which route they choose.

Sometimes their journeys are very far, like the sandpiper. This bird migrates from Canada (in the north of the American continent) to Tierro del-Fuego (at the southern tip of the American continent). Some types of swifts fly as far as 10,000 km from Alaska to Patagonia, Chile. Swifts in Scandinavia (Northern Europe) fly to southern Africa in winter. The very small warbler, weighing less than an ounce, flies at night from Germany to Africa in the run-up to winter. Uniquely, this bird flies individually. Not flying in groups like other types of birds.

The Arctic tern is the long-distance flying champion. They mate and raise their young in the Arctic during the summer, and spend the winter in the Antarctic. Allah says:

Do you not see that Allah is exalted by whomever is within the heavens and the earth and [by] the birds with wings spread [in flight]? Each [of them] has known his [means of] prayer and exalting [Him], and Allah is Knowing of what they do. (an-Nur/24: 41)

We know that birds can fly, because Allah 'holds' them in the air. They migrate along mysterious paths because they are carrying out Allah's plan. They fly as part of their glorification (tasbih) to Allah the Creator. A turtledove does not want to be an eagle. The crow does not care that its feather color is not as beautiful as a parrot's. A honeyeater will not try to catch fish instead of honey. That is a lesson for all of us who can think.

Who taught the bird to fly spreading its wings? In fact, who created the bird with a specific shape, and equipped it with organs (tools) so that it is able to fly and not fall to the earth? Why can't a horse fly like a bird? If humans want to think about all that has been mentioned, they will be sure that Allah is indeed the Creator, the All-Powerful, the Most Generous, and the All-Knowing of everything He created.
text.20:
Allah reproaches the disbelievers who worship objects of worship besides Allah with a question that states that no one will come to help them and release them from Allah's punishment. They have been deceived by the whispers of Satan who instill the belief in their hearts that these idols can help and grant their requests. In reality, this is not the case. The idols themselves cannot do anything at all; on the contrary, it is humans who determine everything for themselves. The disbelievers are deceived by the whispers of Satan. Therefore, Allah says:

And they worship besides Allah that which neither benefits them nor harms them. And the disbeliever is ever a helper (to Satan) against his Lord. (al-Furqan/25: 55)

The phrase "min dunir-rahman" (besides Allah, the Most Gracious) implies that Allah's mercy is bestowed upon all creatures in this universe, both those who believe in Allah and those who disbelieve. Likewise, to animals, plants, and so on, so that they can all live and develop. However, in the Hereafter, that mercy will only be given to those who believe. Allah says:

Say, "Who has forbidden the adornment of Allah which He has produced for His servants and the good [lawful] things of provision?" Say, "They are for those who believe during the worldly life [but] exclusively for them on the Day of Resurrection." Thus do We detail the verses for a people who know. (al-A'raf/7: 32)
text.21:
To the disbelievers who deny Allah's provision, a statement is conveyed in the form of a question: that no one can provide sustenance if Allah withholds it from them. They are asked to contemplate, if Allah no longer sends down rain, withers all vegetation so that the entire surface of the earth becomes dry and barren, causes all livestock that can be eaten to die, makes the sun stop rising in the east and makes the day continuously bright without changing to darkness, how and from where would they obtain sustenance?

Then it is explained that the disbelievers actually believe in the oneness and power of Allah. They associate partners with Allah only driven by their arrogance and unwillingness to accept the truth because they fear losing their position and influence in their society. This arrogance and denial arise and are nurtured by the deception and temptations of Satan, who always cultivates feelings in their minds and imaginations that their bad deeds are good and commendable deeds. Indeed, that is the purpose of Satan's life in this world.

Allah says:

(Allah) said, "Then get down from it [Paradise], as it is not for you to be arrogant therein. So get out; indeed, you are of the degraded." (Iblis) said, "Reprieve me until the Day they are resurrected." (Allah) said, "Indeed, you are of those reprieved." (al-A'raf/7: 13-15)
text.22:
In this verse, Allah provides a comparison for mankind between the path of life taken by the disbelievers and the path taken by the believers. This comparison is given in the form of a question stating that a person who constantly stumbles or falls while walking, whose feet are always tripping because they are traversing a rocky and potholed road, cannot possibly be safe and walk faster to reach their destination compared to a person who walks in a good and safe environment, on a flat and smooth road, and in good weather.

The comparison in the verse above is presented in the form of a question. The question in this verse is not intended to inquire about something unknown, but to express an intention, namely that the actions of the disbelievers are incorrect actions. It is stated that the life journey of the disbelievers is a journey towards immense misery and suffering. It is as if this verse states that surely a person who walks face down, with their face sweeping the ground, will easily get lost on their journey navigating the ocean of life in this fleeting world, and in the Hereafter they will be cast into a blazing Hellfire. Whereas, a person who walks in a good way, taking a good and straight path, namely the path that is pleasing to Allah, will not get lost on their life journey in this world and will surely reach the goal that they desire and that is pleasing to Allah. In the Hereafter, they will occupy a Paradise full of delights that Allah has prepared for those who are pious.

Furthermore, it can also be understood from this verse that in carrying out their endeavors, performing their work, and fulfilling their obligations, humans must be based on the provisions of the Islamic religion, the guidance of knowledge, sound reason and experience, as well as the results of research by previous experts. This is so that their efforts and work will produce good results. They should not act blindly or work as they please, because that will only invite failure and disaster, both for themselves and others.
text.23:
Furthermore, in this verse, Allah commands mankind to pay attention to the creation of themselves. Allah commands Prophet Muhammad to say to the disbelievers that it is indeed Allah who bestowed upon mankind ears so that they can hear the teachings of His religion conveyed to them by the messengers. Allah also bestowed upon them eyes so that they can see, observe, and pay attention to the events of this universe. He gave them hearts, intellect, and minds to think, contemplate, weigh, and distinguish between what is good for them and what is not, what is beneficial and what is not. In reality, with Allah's grace, humans can achieve all that is good for themselves as His creation.

Indeed, hearing, sight, and the heart are a unity. Hearing and sight are devices used by humans to understand the verses of Allah, *sunnatullah*, which can be used (applied) in the development of science and technology, to meet human needs. The method of observation in scientific and technological discoveries is highly dependent on the use of hearing and sight devices. However, if only hearing and sight devices are used, and the heart (*al-af'idah*) is ignored in the decision of its application, then the result will be counterproductive, which will give more harm than benefit. In essence, the heart (*al-af'idah*) must be used as a guide in making decisions for the application of science and technology, which are produced by the method of hearing and sight. From *al-af'idah* can be developed science ethics based on Islamic values.

Very few people are willing to be grateful to Allah for the blessings He has given them. Very few people realize their dependence on these blessings, even though if only a little of that blessing is suspended from being given to them or taken away by God, they feel a very great difficulty. At that moment they remember Him. However, when they regain that blessing and the difficulty has passed, they return to disbelief in Allah.
text.24: Allah commands that the Prophet Muhammad convey to the disbelievers that He has created them all in different forms and with various skin colors, providing them with places on earth and scattering them to every corner of the earth. It is Allah who has made it easy for them to master and cultivate the earth for their life and livelihood. Therefore, it is only to Allah that they will return and be held accountable for all the deeds they have done during their life on earth. In the Hereafter, Allah will justly reward them all. Good deeds will be rewarded with manifold rewards, while evil deeds will be punished with the torment of hellfire commensurate with the evil of their deeds.
text.25:
The disbelievers asked the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) mockingly and defiantly about when the time would come for them to be struck by collapsing earth, a violent wind mixed with stones that would blow and hurl them, as a punishment that was often mentioned as befalling the disbelievers? When would the Day of Judgment come, on which day all of humanity's deeds during their life in the world would be accounted for, and they, as the disobedient, would enter Hell? They asked for all of this to be explained, if the Prophet was among those whose words could be trusted.

From the questions of these disbelievers, it is understood that they were challenging the truth conveyed by the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), because according to them, what was threatened was impossible to happen. According to them, it should be Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and his followers who would be punished, and in reality, they had been punished by Allah in the world, in the form of misery and torment inflicted upon them, such as poverty, destitution, and the punishments given by the disbelievers of Mecca to them. The disbelievers said that what Muhammad (peace and blessings be upon him) and his followers would receive in the Hereafter would be heavier than the punishment they received in the world.
text.26:
In this verse, Allah commands the Messenger of Allah to answer the words of the disbelievers by saying, "O disbelievers, only Allah knows all that you ask. Because, regarding when the punishment will come, and the occurrence of the Day of Judgment, it is part of the unseen knowledge, which only Allah knows. As for myself, I am nothing but a messenger and envoy of Allah who has been given the task of conveying His religion to you all, so that you may live happily in this world and in the Hereafter. I am commanded by Him to convey the news to you that the punishment will surely befall the disbelievers and the Day of Judgment will surely occur."

In another verse, Allah says:

"People ask you, [O Muhammad], about the Hour. Say, "Knowledge of it is only with Allah." And what may make you perceive? Perhaps the Hour is near." (al-Ahzab/33: 63)

From that answer, it can be understood that the Messenger of Allah is only an ordinary human being and has characteristics and abilities like ordinary human beings as well. His advantage lies only in the task given to him. Besides his nature as an ordinary human being, he is given the task of conveying the religion of Allah. Therefore, he does not know the unseen except if Allah informs him. His task is not to make someone believe, but solely to convey the religion of Allah and give explanations to mankind. In another verse, Allah says:

"We are most knowing of what they say, and you are not over them a tyrant. But remind, by the Qur'an, whoever fears My threat." (Qaf/50: 45)

Another saying of Allah:

"Not upon you, [O Muhammad], is [responsibility for] their guidance, but Allah guides whom He wills." (al-Baqarah/2: 272)
text.27:
This verse explains that the hearts of the disbelievers become shrunken and the color of their faces changes after they are certain of the nearness of the promised punishment on the Day of Judgment and the horror that will befall them on that day. They are in a state of constant fear and regret. At that time, the angels say, "This is the Day of Judgment and the punishment of Allah that you denied when you were alive in the world, and you even used to demand its arrival."

In another verse, Allah says:

And there will become apparent to them the evil of what they earned, and they will be enveloped by what they used to ridicule. (az-Zumar/39: 48)
text.28:
The Messenger of Allah (saw) called upon the disbelievers to believe in Allah, the One and Only, and explained that those who worship idols are foolish, because they worship something that cannot bring benefit or harm. As a reaction to the Messenger of Allah's call, they said to their friends, "Just wait until our gods kill or harm Muhammad and his followers. If they are all destroyed or killed, they will certainly stop spreading their religion on their own. At that time, we will be free from their disturbances and incitements."

Is not Allah sufficient for His servant? And [yet], they threaten you with those [they worship] other than Him. And whoever Allah leaves astray - for him there will be no guide. (az-Zumar/39: 36)

Allah refutes their words by commanding Prophet Muhammad to say to them, "O polytheists, explain to me, what benefit and advantage will you gain if your prayers are answered by the idols you worship besides Allah, while I and all those who believe are destroyed and die? Will my destruction and the destruction of those who believe with me free you from the punishment of Allah whom you disobey? Do you not remember that it has been decreed that punishment will be given to everyone who denies Him and always commits evil? Have you never thought about the consequences of your prayers, O disbelievers? Even if I and my followers all die and He puts us into the Paradise that He has promised us, will you be free from the punishment of Allah, and who can save you from the punishment of Allah?"

The answer conveyed by the Messenger of Allah (saw) above is a very appropriate answer and influences the hearts and minds of the polytheists, because the one who conveyed the words to them was someone they trusted, respected, and acknowledged as their leader. That person was Prophet Muhammad, whom they had entrusted to resolve disputes that occurred among them, and they acknowledged that his resolution was the most appropriate and fair. Although the teachings conveyed by Muhammad were different from the beliefs they held, the personality of Muhammad was an answer that could be accepted by those who wanted to use their minds correctly.
text.29:
Allah commanded Prophet Muhammad to say to the disbelievers of Mecca, "O disbelievers; I and my followers have believed in the Lord of the universe, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful to His servants, the Lord who establishes justice with fairness. To Him alone do we submit ourselves and all our affairs, because He is the One who determines our condition and to Him alone do we seek help, because He alone gives help and provides us with sustenance for our survival and our lives. He alone can free us from all disasters and calamities that may befall us."

This verse seems to rebuke the attitude and actions of the disbelievers who worship idols that they themselves made, which cannot provide benefit or harm, and they themselves even have to maintain and care for them. Similarly, the attitude of the disbelievers who always boast about their wealth, power, and lineage, as Allah says:

"And they say, 'We are more (than you) in wealth and children, and we will not be punished.'" (Saba'/34: 35)

Because of that disbelief, they will not obtain the pleasures of life in the Hereafter. They will know later, who among them and the believers are on the right path and who are on the wrong path. Those who take the right path will arrive at a good place full of enjoyment, and those who take the wrong path will certainly arrive at a wrong place as well, full of misery and suffering.
text.30:
In this verse, Allah explains further the signs of His greatness and power, after in the previous verse He commanded to put trust in Him (tawakal). Allah commands Muhammad to say to the disbelievers, "O disbelievers, try to explain to me, what do you think, if by the will of Allah all the water flowing on the surface of the earth were to seep into the ground, so that your water sources and wells become dry, your buckets can no longer draw water. Can your other gods bring that water, so that you can drink, your gardens become fertile again and your livestock can thrive? There is nothing that can bring that water except Allah, the Most Gracious and Most Merciful to His servants. Why do you still associate partners with Him with something that is not worthy of Him?"

This verse commands the disbelievers to compare the basis of divinity according to their understanding with the nature of understanding of divinity according to the religion conveyed by Muhammad saw. The God who is worshipped according to what the Messenger of Allah taught is the God who created all creatures, and maintains the continuity of life of all that lives in this universe. He is All-Powerful and All-Determining of everything, not needing anything to help Him and so on. Not a God made by humans or appointed by humans themselves to be worshipped, like the understanding of divinity of the polytheists. This verse seems to remind them that the God who deserves to be worshipped is only the One God, who does not beget, is not begotten, does not associate with anything, and does not need other creatures to help Him carry out every affair.
